inventory.bat_description: Sep 24 at 10:45 PM2x99qcaThis author's likes:70I own one of these cars (in California). There are no emissions issues.More importantly: these cars are exceptional. The engine screams with a beautiful tone, it loves long high revs. Car is bulletproof as long as IMS is done (or at least has been in my case). The whole package feels very lightweight, tossable, and extremely analog. The German tightness is fairly crazy, from the pedal box to the springs. These things will still be great at 100,000 miles, yet many have low mileage like this one because they were allocated thus bought as third+ cars, not second cars.CancelYour changes are being saved.This comment's likes:2This comment's likes:2This comment's likes:2Flag as not constructiveFlag as not constructiveFlagged as not constructive — Thanks.Edit

inventory.bat_description: This 1992 Porsche 911 is one of 45 Carrera Cup models sent to the US to be converted by Andial for participation in a planned single-make racing series. When Porsche canceled the series before it began, the cars were distributed to dealers for public sale. This example was originally delivered to Reeves Import Motor Cars in Tampa, Florida, and was sent to Gunnar Racing in October 1992 to be reconverted for track use with Andial-sourced equipment including a welded-in roll cage, Recaro racing seats, Schroth harnesses, a Momo steering wheel, coilover suspension, wider 17″ Cup 1 wheels, and a muffler-delete pipe. Finished in Grand Prix White, the car is powered by a 3.6-liter M64 flat-six and five-speed G50 transaxle as well as a limited-slip differential, an aluminum hood, chassis reinforcements, Turbo-style brakes, manual steering, a fuel cell, and 18″ BBS wheels. inventory.bat_description: Sep 11 at 4:26 PMAdoderoThis author's likes:188There are a few spots on the car that I’d call corrosion a potential concern or need more investigation. I am not an expert in these cars, but I’ve seen enough on those I’ve owned and others to know where to look. It’s a safe rule that, despite being galvanized, these cars are all rusting if you know where to look. All of them. The only real rust free examples are cars that have been disassembled in a quest to locate and eliminate corrosion, the rest will have it in some places, yes even if it’s a CA car. It’s even harder because Porsche adhesives look exactly like rust, so it’s hard to differentiate in photos.Some of this is due to age, a lot is due to design flaws and the lack of plastic shielding around the wheel wells that most modern cars have. They fling dirt, debris, and moisture up into bad places where it sits and corrodes over time. You will be hard pressed to find any 911 of this era or earlier that isn’t rusting somewhere, you

inventory.bat_description: This 1995 Porsche 911 Carrera RS is one of a reported 227 examples optioned with the track-focused M003 Clubsport package, which was designed in an effort to homologate the car for the BPR GT3 and GT4 categories. Delivered new to Austria, the car was specified in Riviera Blue with air conditioning. Power comes from a 3.8-liter flat-six mated to a six-speed manual transaxle and a limited-slip differential, and equipment includes 18″ Speedline multi-piece wheels, a front strut tower brace, a roll cage, Recaro seats with body-color shells, Schroth Racing six-point harnesses, and a leather-wrapped MOMO steering wheel. It was acquired by the current owner in 2018, and work in June 2025 involved repairing oil leaks, servicing the brakes, and replacing the front tires, spark plugs, and a rear trailing arm. This 993 RS Clubsport shows 39k kilometers (~24k miles) and is now offered on dealer consignment in Monmouthshire, Wales, with a Porsche Certificate of Authenticity, service records, and UK

inventory.bat_description: This 1996 Porsche 911 Carrera coupe is a rest-of-world example that was purchased by the current owner in 2020 and imported to the US in 2024, and it shows 54k kilometers (~34k miles). Powered by a 3.6-liter flat-six paired with a four-speed Tiptronic transaxle, the car is finished in Grand Prix White over black leather upholstery. Equipment includes 17″ Cup II wheels, Bilstein coilover suspension, a power-operated sunroof, a speed-activated rear spoiler, heated and power-adjustable front seats, cruise control, air conditioning, and a Blaupunkt Bremen head unit. This 993 Carrera coupe is offered in California by the seller on behalf of the owner with offered with a clean Carfax report and a clean Montana title in the name of the owner’s LLC.The car is finished in Grand Prix White and features headlight washers, fog lights, power-adjustable mirrors, a power-operated sunroof, a speed-activated rear spoiler, a rear window wiper, and dual exhaust outlets. inventory.bat_description: This 1995 Porsche 911 Carrera RS is one of approximately 1,014 examples produced for the 1995 and 1996 model years, and it was sold new viaMizwaMotors in Japan. It was imported to the US by the selling dealer under the NHTSA Show or Display exemption in 2013 and was subsequently federalized by JK Technologies of Baltimore, Maryland, before it was purchased by the current owner later that year. The car is finished in Polar Silver Metallic over two-tone black and gray leather upholstery, and power comes from a 3.8-liter flat-six mated to a six-speed manual transaxle and a limited-slip differential. Equipment includes a seam-welded body shell, an aluminum hood, front and rear spoilers, 18″ Speedline multi-piece wheels, a front strut tower bar, air conditioning, power-operated windows, front airbags, and a Porsche CDR-220 head unit. inventory.bat_description: This 1995 Porsche 911 Carrera RS is one of approximately 1,014 examples produced for the 1995 and 1996 model years and spent several years in Italy before moving to Sweden approximately 10 years ago. A 2021 mechanical service performed by Porsche in Stuttgart totaled over €37,000 (~$43k) and included an overhaul of the six-speed manual transaxle along with a refresh of the engine, ignition system, chassis, and air conditioning system. Finished in black over black leather, the car is powered by a 3.8-liter M64/20 flat-six and features a seam-welded body shell, an aluminum hood, front and rear spoilers, cross-drilled and ventilated disc brakes with red-painted calipers, adjustable anti-roll bars, a front strut tower bar, staggered-width 18″ Speedline multi-piece wheels, sport seats, and a cassette player. It was imported to the US in 2023 and was purchased by its current owner in 2024. This Carrera RS is now offered in Monterey, California on dealer consignment as part of the Mohr Import

inventory.bat_description: This 1997 Porsche 911 Carrera S coupe was produced for sale in the Japanese market and was imported to Canada in 2025. The car was specified in Arctic Silver Metallic over black partial leather, and it was optioned without a sunroof. Additional features include 18″ Turbo Twist wheels, Bilstein coilovers, a JVC head unit, cruise control, and air conditioning. Power comes from a 3.6-liter flat-six paired with a four-speed Tiptronic transaxle, and the car has traveled approximately 78k kilometers (~48k miles). This 993 C2S is now offered in Canada by the seller on behalf of the owner, a retail dealer, with the owner’s manual, a CTEK battery maintainer, a clean Carfax report, and clean British Columbia registration.The 993 C2S featured wider bodywork, a split rear grille, and revised bumper covers and side skirts compared to the contemporary Carrera.
